name: Bat-eared Fox
description: A small carnivore with a pointed snout and striking ear flaps that exceed the length of its head. It’s mostly brown, with black legs and white inner ear flaps.
spread_note: Two separate ranges in southern and eastern Africa
proportions: Body length 46–66 cm; tail length 23–34 cm; shoulder height 30–40 cm; weight 3–5.5 kg
attractions: In hot African savannas, its large ears serve multiple purposes—dissipating excess body heat and catching faint sounds from insects, its primary food. It specializes in termites and beetles. To handle small prey, it has tiny but numerous teeth—up to 48, more than most mammals. Bat-eared foxes live in small family groups. Their young are born in burrows dug by the parents.
breeding: We’ve kept bat-eared foxes since 1980, though one likely appeared in the 1950s. The first successful breeding was in 1987.
